identity.biochemicalTests: Gram-variable coccobacillus, catalase –, oxidase –, hippurate hydrolysis +, beta-hemolytic on human blood agar.

clinicalProfile.summary: Gardnerella vaginalis is a key player in bacterial vaginosis (BV), a polymicrobial condition characterized by a shift in the vaginal flora away from lactobacilli towards a mixed anaerobic population. While G. vaginalis can be found in asymptomatic women, its overgrowth, in synergy with other anaerobes, leads to the characteristic signs and symptoms of BV.
pathophysiologyPearls: G. vaginalis produces a sialidase that can degrade cervical mucus, potentially facilitating ascending infections.
It forms a dense biofilm on the vaginal epithelium, which is a hallmark of bacterial vaginosis and contributes to treatment failure and recurrence.
keySignsAndSymptoms: Malodorous "fishy" vaginal odor, especially after intercourse
Presence of "clue cells" on wet mount microscopy
Minimal or absent vaginal inflammation, itching, or irritation

clinicalSyndromes.description: A vaginal dysbiosis resulting from an overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria, including G. vaginalis, leading to a characteristic malodorous discharge.

highRiskPopulations: Women with new or multiple sexual partners
transmissionVectors: Primarily associated with sexual activity, though it is not considered a classic STI as it can be found in women who are not sexually active.
prognosisNotes: Bacterial vaginosis is associated with an increased risk of acquiring other STIs, including HIV, and can lead to complications in pregnancy such as preterm birth.

generalNotes: Treatment is aimed at relieving symptoms and reducing the risk of complications. Asymptomatic colonization does not require treatment.
Single-dose metronidazole (2g) is not recommended due to lower efficacy.

testingIndications: Symptomatic women complaining of vaginal discharge or odor.
methodologyNotes: Diagnosis is typically made using Amsel's criteria (requires 3 of 4: thin, white discharge; pH >4.5; positive whiff test; >20% clue cells) or by Nugent scoring of a Gram-stained vaginal smear.

specialTests.purpose: To identify clue cells, which are vaginal epithelial cells studded with coccobacilli, obscuring the cell borders.
Addition of 10% KOH to vaginal discharge releases a characteristic fishy odor due to the volatilization of amines.

diagnosticNotes.summary: Diagnosis is clinical, based on Amsel's criteria, or by Nugent score. Culture of G. vaginalis is not recommended for diagnosis as it is found in many asymptomatic women.
diagnosticNotes.biosafetyWarning: Standard precautions are sufficient for handling clinical specimens.

drugSpecificPearls.pearl: Ovules and creams use an oleaginous base that might weaken latex or rubber products like condoms and diaphragms.
